data.title: Nathaniel Gorham – Family History Ralph Gorham of Benefield ...
data.meta_description: Nathaniel Gorham – Family History Ralph Gorham of Benefield ...
data.text: Nathaniel Gorham – Family History Ralph Gorham of Benefield, Northamptonshire, immigrated to America on the ship Phillip in 1635, accompanied by his son John Gorham, then about fifteen years old, baptized in Benefield in January 1620. Settling in Plymouth Colony, Ralph Gorham pursued his profession as a joiner. His son John 1 Gorham married in about 1643, Desire Howland, daughter of John Howland and Elizabeth Tilley, both Mayflower passengers. John Gorham lived in Plymouth, Marshfield, Yarmouth, and finally Barnstable, Massachusetts, where he owned a grist mill and tannery; he was a Captain in the Militia in King Philip’s War and fought at Narragansett in December 1675, when he was wounded “by having his powder horn shot and split against his side”; he died of the resulting fever, and was buried at Swansea, Massachusetts, 5FEB1676/7. His widow Desire (Howland) Gorham, survived him by five years, and her mother, Elizabeth Tilley of the Mayflower, lived until 1686. John Gorham and Desire Howland had five sons and six daughters. Their youngest child, Shubael 2 Gorham, was born in Barnstable in 1667, and married on the Island of Nantucket in May 1695, Puella Hussey, daughter of Stephen Hussey and Martha Bunker, of Nantucket. Shubael was a minor when his father died, and he received £50 from his father’s estate to be “educated in a learned profession”, but he preferred to be a carpenter. When he and his wedding party sailed to Nantucket, they were taken prisoner by a French ship from Port Royal and relieved of their valuables, but released unharmed. He settled his wife at South Sea in Barnstable County and built a tavern near Hyannis Port, where they had two sons and seven daughters. Their youngest son Daniel Gorham died of smallpox in London, England in 1745, leaving his brother and sisters an estate of £960. Shubael Gorham died in 1750, leaving his substantial real estate to his surviving son George. George 3 Gorham, born 1696, was married by a Church of England minister in New Rochelle, New York in July 1726 to Hannah Banks, daughter of Joseph Banks and Hannah Purdy. George was a merchant and sea captain, licensed in 1727 to sail his sloop Hannah between New London CT, Boston, London England, and the West Indies; he owned several grist mills and was a town official of Stamford and Darien, CT. George Gorham and Hannah Banks had five sons and eight daughters. Their firstborn, Shubael 4 Gorham, was born in Greenwich, CT April 1727, and married in Stamford, CT August 1748, Mary Selleck, daughter of Nathaniel Selleck and Mary DeMille; he died about 1771 when many of his children were still young. His widow Mary (Selleck) Gorham married 2 nd Eliakim Whitney, widowed father of her daughter-in-law Mary (Whitney) Gorham, and moved with her youngest children to Ball Town, Albany County, N.Y. Shubael Gorham and Mary Selleck had six sons and three daughters. Three sons sided with the British in the Revolutionary War: Nathaniel, Samuel, and John, who served as an Ensign in the Royal Fencible Americans.
